About Me

My name is Veronica Rivera and I am a second year PhD student in Computational Media at the University of California, Santa Cruz. I am a member of the Assistive Sociotechnical Solutions for Individuals with Special Needs Using Technology (ASSIST) lab and am advised by Professor Sri Kurniawan.

My research is in Human-Computer Interaction, Assistive Technology, Education, and Computer-Supported Cooperative Work. I am primarily focused on creating interactive technology to help students with Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) better learn and work with their peers in the classroom. Before coming to UC Santa Cruz, I obtained a B.S in Joint Computer Science and Mathematics with a Concentration in Psychology at Harvey Mudd College, where I was a 4-year President's Scholar.

Download my CV.

Nelson, Sam.,Rivera, Veronica. (2014). Quantum Enhancements of Involutory Birack Counting Invariants. The Journal of Knot Theory and its Ramifications, 23(7)

Teaching

Introduction to Programming Accelerated (CMPS 12A). UCSC. Fall 2018. Graduate Teaching Assistant. I hold weekly office hours and lead lab section. I also grade exams and oversee undergraduate course tutors. Course instructor--Professor Narges Norouzi
Introduction to Programming in Java (CMPS 5J). UCSC. Spring 2018. Graduate Teaching Assistant. I held weekly office hours and led lab section. Met with course instructor and other teaching assistants weekly to discuss student progress. Course instructor--Professor Dustin Adams
Introduction to Programming in Java (CMPS 5J). UCSC. Winter 2018. Graduate Teaching Assistant. I held weekly office hours and led lab section. Met with course instrucot and other teaching assistants weekly to discuss student progress. Course instructor--Professor Dustin Adams
